I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the 2002 Country Programming Mission of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), 
the Government of Pakistan requested technical assistance (TA) to prepare a road development 
sector project in the North-West Frontier Province (NWFP). ADB’s Fact-Finding Mission visited 
the  project  area  in  March  2003;  carried  out  an  initial  social  assessment;  and  discussed 
economic,  social,  and  Project-specific  issues  with  officials  of  the  central  and  provincial 
governments.  This  report  is  based  on  the  understanding  reached  with  the  Government 
concerning  the  objectives,  scope,  terms  of  reference,  cost,  financing,  and  implementation 
arrangements for the TA. The TA is included in ADB’s Country Strategy and Program Update 
(CSPU) for 2002.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Poverty. In Pakistan2 the incidence of poverty increased from 26.6% in FY1993 to 
32.2%  in  FY1999.  During  that  period,  the  number  of  poor  increased  by  12  million.  This 
unfavorable development coincided with the onset of the macroeconomic crisis in FY1997 and 
the slowdown in economic growth during that period. Poverty is largely a rural phenomenon in 
Pakistan, and about 77% or 108 million people live in rural areas of the total population of 140 
million. Rural poverty rose sharply in the 1990s, and in FY1999 its incidence (36.3%) was 
significantly higher than urban poverty (22.6%). With a population of close to 20 million, NWFP 
is one of the poorest provinces in Pakistan; currently 31% of the urban and 47% of the rural 
population live below the poverty line – far higher than the national average.3 ADB is actively 
engaged in policy dialogue with the Government on poverty reduction and related issues. The 
poverty focus is emphasized in the CSPU for 2002; the poverty partnership agreement between 
the Federal Government and ADB was signed in 2002. 
 
3.  Programs  to  Reduce  Poverty.  The  Government  is,  inter  alia,  prioritizing  critical 
infrastructure development, including rehabilitation of roads, to reduce poverty. This follows from 
the international experience that road transport often plays an important role in the income 
generation and redistribution process with direct effects, such as providing basic access to 
education, health, and markets and improving access to social and economic opportunities, 
including labor and product markets, schools, and clinics. Road transport also contributes to 
empowerment of the poor, enabling their participation in community and wider decision making, 
and  overcoming  social,  cultural,  and  physical  barriers,  including  geographical  isolation. 
Adequate road transport makes it possible for constituents to get to meeting places and town 
centers,  and  facilitates  the  flow  of  information,  thereby  increasing  political  and  social 
participation. 
 
4.  Road Access and Connectivity.  NWFP has a road network of approximately 14,000 
kilometers (km)4, which represents about 5.6% of the total road network of 249,959 km in 
Pakistan.5 NWFP is landlocked, as the country’s only port is over 1,500 km away to the south. 
Major parts of the road network in NWFP are in very poor condition.6 These major physical 
constraints  reduce  the  prospects  for  pro-poor  economic  growth  and  poverty  reduction. 
According to the initial poverty and social analysis (Appendix 1), the limited road access and

5.  Subregional  Transport  and  Cooperation.    Because  of  its  location,  Pakistan,  in 
particular NWFP is well placed to act as a hub for subregional transport and cooperation, by 
more  effectively  and  closely  linking  landlocked  Afghanistan,  Central  Asia,  and  Pakistan. 
National Highway No. 5 (NH5)7 traverses NWFP and links Pakistan with Afghanistan and its 
capital, Kabul. NH5 is increasingly being used as a transit route for the landlocked countries in 
Central Asia and Afghanistan, offering access to major parts of Pakistan including Islamabad 
and Lahore as well as ports in Gwadar and Karachi. While both intraregional and interregional 
trade are expected to increase during the coming years, partly because of the reconstruction of 
critical infrastructure in Afghanistan, improved trade facilitation and streamlined cross-border 
arrangements along with rehabilitation and expansion of the road network will be important to 
meet the expected increase in transport demand, particularly for freight. This would place 
considerable pressure on the existing road network in NWFP, which is already in poor condition. 
Increased trade, facilitation, and transit traffic will also raise the incomes of the rural poor 
residing along the major transit routes in NWFP, such as national and provincial highways, and 
will provide better access to economic opportunities as well as education, health, and other 
social services. 
 
6.  Road Sector Development and Assistance in Afghanistan and Central Asia. The 
road network in Afghanistan is in an extremely poor state following two decades of war and civil 
unrest.  Road  sector  institutions  are  weak  or  absent  and  lack  physical  and  administrative 
resources as well as institutional capacity. To address these shortcomings, a large TA8 was 
approved in May 2002 focusing on institutional development and capacity building and other 
important  activities.  In  addition,  a  loan  for  rehabilitation  of  critical  infrastructure  is  being 
processed for approval during 2003. ADB is also active in Central Asia, supporting subregional 
cooperation and removal of impediments to cross-border road transport through regional TA9 
and/or financing of road rehabilitation projects in Kyrgyz Republic and Tajikistan. 
 
7.  Institutional  Capacity  and  Constraints.    In  1970,  NWFP  established  a 
Communications and Works Department (CWD) after the formation of the four provinces. CWD 
was responsible for both roads and buildings, in particular the construction and maintenance of 
provincial roads. In August 2001, several institutional changes took place in NWFP. The Frontier 
Highway Authority (FHA) was established as an autonomous body for construction, operation, 
repair, and maintenance of the eight provincial highways (2,059 km) in NWFP and other roads 
specially entrusted to it by the provincial government. In addition, the remaining functions of 
CWD  were  merged  with  two  other  departments,  Public  Health  Engineering  and  Physical 
Planning and Housing, into a new department, called the Works and Services Department 
(W&S). As a consequence of the devolution process, which was formally initiated in August 
2001, further institutional measures have to be implemented over the medium term. These 
changes include, inter alia, organizational changes at W&S, FHA, and the districts, and adoption 
of modern management systems and principles and of financial management and accounting 
systems with appropriate audit systems, all of which are in support of good governance.  
 
8.  Road Maintenance.  At the provincial government and FHA levels, there is increasing 
recognition  that  additional  emphasis  and  spending  on  road  maintenance  is  necessary  to 
preserve the provincial road infrastructure asset base and prevent early deterioration of the 
provincial  and  district  road  networks.  Key  road  maintenance  issues  in  NWFP  include  (i)

the existing road asset management system and extending it to districts; (iii) introducing the 
Highway Design and Maintenance Model at FHA and gradually, over time, to districts; (iv) 
building capacity at FHA and at the district level in modern road management principles and 
road  maintenance;  (v)  providing  an  adequate,  stable,  secure,  and  sustainable  source  of 
maintenance funds for the network;10 and (vi) ensuring transparency and accountability in the 
road maintenance funding process and possible establishment of a road fund. 
 
9.  Axle Load Control.  The control of axle loads has long been recognized as a serious 
problem in reducing maintenance and rehabilitation expenditures. Vehicle overloading is a 
major issue impeding sustainable development of road sections in Pakistan, specifically in 
NWFP.  Surveys  conducted  by  road  agencies  indicate  that  trucks  and  tractor  trailers  are 
generally loaded beyond capacity, resulting in axle load 3-4 times the allowable single axle load 
of 12 tons. This causes roads to deteriorate rapidly, reducing their service life and significantly 
reducing  the  economic  benefits  that  should  have  been  realized  during  their  design  life. 
Moreover, the high recurrent costs of maintenance and the need for virtual reconstruction in 
most  cases  erode  the  limited  development  resources  of  the  province.  NWFP  needs  to 
accelerate installation of weigh stations at strategic locations and introduce a fine collection 
system to address this escalating problem along with better enforcement of rules and regulation.  
 
10.  Road Safety. A major issue in Pakistan is road safety as the fatality rate on the country's 
road network remains among the highest in South Asia. The total fatalities to vehicle ratio in 
Pakistan is about 10 times higher than that in developed countries. The causes are the higher 
motor  vehicle  density,  higher  speeds,  lack  of  road  safety  measures, poor discipline and 
enforcement, and poor roadworthiness of vehicles. Road safety audits are not conducted 
routinely for all new and improved roads. 
 
11.  Private Sector Participation.  While the opportunities for private sector participation in 
road infrastructure projects are generally somewhat limited in NWFP due to the low traffic 
levels, potential areas include contracting out of maintenance, toll operations for congested 
roads, and network management. 
 
12.  Lessons  Learned.  While  the  World  Bank  has  focused  mainly  on  and  provided 
assistance to the national road network administered by the National Highway Authority (NHA) 
at the federal level, ADB has targeted development of the provincial road networks.11 ADB has 
approved eight12 loans, totaling $897 million, for Pakistan’s road sector, four of which have been 
for umbrella projects that include components in each of the country’s four provinces.13 That 
arrangement has resulted in fragmentation of effort; coordination problems; and weakening of 
the dialogue on critical policy issues such as road management and maintenance, institutional 
reform, procurement, and procedures at the provincial level. Moreover, the wide geographic 
dispersion of the projects and the large number of government agencies has limited the impact 
on  the  individual  provinces,  and  project  implementation  has  suffered  from  delays  and 
implementation problems. ADB’s adopted provincial focus in the road sector in Pakistan draws 
on these lessons.

13.  Road Sector Development Strategy. While maintaining a continuing relationship with 
the World Bank and the federal agencies for the national highway network, ADB is now focusing 
on sustainable development of provincial road sector institutions and networks, allowing for 
greater ownership, accountability, and development impact. Adopting a sectorwide approach 
that sequences interventions in individual provinces over several years, the emphasis is on road 
sector policy reform at the provincial and district levels, support for capacity building, removal of 
capacity bottlenecks, and physical rehabilitation of critical parts of the provincial road network, 
all having a positive impact on poverty reduction and pro-poor economic growth.14  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
14.  The objective of the TA is to assist the Government to prepare an integrated road 
development project, comprising a policy and investment program, for NWFP that will support 
sustainable pro-poor growth, reduce poverty, promote subregional cooperation, and be suitable 
for external financing.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
15.  The TA will assist the provincial government of NWFP, W&S, and FHA to review existing 
institutional capacity and road sector policies and regulations, including impediments to cross-
border trade and traffic, and propose changes to address identified constraints for sustainable 
development of the road sector. Specifically, the TA will (i) identify prevailing policy constraints 
and institutional shortcomings in the road sector and recommend changes thereto; (ii) assess 
prospects and impediments for increased subregional trade and traffic, specifically cross-border 
arrangements and major physical bottlenecks; (iii) identify, screen, and prioritize about 2,500 km 
of candidate roads based on the TA objective and on economic, social, and other criteria; (iv) 
update existing feasibility studies and prepare new ones, as appropriate, for the roads15 to be 
included in the proposed Project; (v) update and carry out, as appropriate, detailed design and 
engineering for the selected national and provincial highways and five core rural access roads; 
(vi) carry out social analysis, poverty impact, and environmental assessments for selected roads 
in accordance with ADB’s relevant guidelines; (vii) confirm the economic viability and poverty 
impact of selected roads; (viii) propose suitable contract packaging; (ix) prepare complete civil 
works bidding documents following ADB’s  Guidelines on Procurement  and Sample Bidding 
Documents for Civil Works; and (x) propose Project implementation arrangements and prepare 
schedules for project completion. There are no major risks associated with the TA, and the 
provincial government of NWFP has expressed its strong support for it.

C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The  total  cost  of  the  TA  is  estimated  at  $620,000  equivalent  including  a  foreign 
exchange cost of $202,000 and a local currency cost of $418,000 equivalent. The detailed cost 
estimates are in Appendix 2. ADB will finance $490,000 equivalent, including the entire foreign 
exchange cost and local currency costs of $288,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a 
grant basis from the ADB-funded TA program. The Government will finance the remaining local 
currency costs of $130,000 equivalent. The Government has been advised that approval of the 
TA does not commit ADB to financing any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  W&S will be the Executing Agency. An experienced project director placed under the 
Secretary  of  W&S  has  already  been  appointed  and  will  be  responsible  for  day-to-day 
management and administration of the TA. W&S will be responsible for providing office and 
support  facilities,  counterpart  staff,  documentation,  and  other  required  services.  NHA  will 
appoint a project coordinator at the national level who will be responsible for all communications 
and  coordination  with  the  TA  consultants.  To  provide  overall  guidance  during  TA 
implementation, a steering committee16 will be established by NWFP. 
 
18.  The TA will require 43 person-months of consulting services, comprising 8 person-
months of international consultants and 35 person-months of domestic consultants, to carry out 
the activities as defined in the outline terms of reference (Appendix 3). A team of consultants, 
from an international consulting firm in association with domestic consultants, will be engaged 
using ADB’s quality and cost-based selection procedures and according to ADB’s Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB on the engagement of 
domestic consultants.17 The international consultants will have expertise in (i) transport policy 
and  economics,  and  (ii)  social  and  poverty  analysis  including  resettlement  planning.  The 
domestic consultants will have expertise in (i) transport economics, (ii) highway and bridge 
design including structural engineering, (iii) geotechnical analysis and materials engineering, (iv) 
traffic  engineering,  (v)  surveying,  (vi)  procurement  and  contract  management,  (vii) 
environmental analysis, (viii) social and poverty analysis, and (ix) resettlement planning. 
 
19.  The TA consultants are expected to be fielded in August 2003 and to be finished in 
December  2003;  the  consulting  services  will  be  carried  out  over  5  months.  During  TA 
implementation, workshops and tripartite meetings involving the provincial government, NHA, 
ADB, the consultants, and other stakeholders will be held in NWFP, as needed. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $490,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Pakistan for preparing the North-West Frontier Road Development Sector 
Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Objective 
 
1.  The objective of the technical assistance (TA) is to assist the Government, the Works 
and Services Department (W&S), and the Frontier Highway Authority (FHA) to prepare an 
integrated roads development project, comprising a policy and investment program, for North-
West Frontier Province (NWFP) that will support sustainable pro-poor growth, reduce poverty, 
promote subregional cooperation, and be suitable for external financing.  
 
B.  Scope 
 
2.  Policy Program. The consultants will review existing institutional arrangements at W&S 
and FHA and assess road sector policies and regulation, including impediments to cross-border 
trade  and  traffic,  and  propose  changes  necessary  to  address  identified  constraints  for 
sustainable development of the road sector in NWFP over the medium term. Priority areas for 
detailed  assessment  and  review  include  (i)  policies,  regulations,  and  administrative 
arrangements  for  international  road  traffic  including  cross-border  arrangements;  (ii)  the 
institutional setup and capacity at W&S, FHA, and the district level; (iii) capacity building and 
training needs at W&S, FHA, and the districts; (iv) maintenance organization and mechanisms 
for secure and stable funding for road maintenance including establishment of a road fund; (v) 
governance,  specifically  financial  management  and  accounting  systems,  including  audit 
functions;  (vi)  private  sector  involvement  in  operations,  maintenance,  and  civil  works 
construction; (vii) road safety; (viii) axle load control; and (ix) the use of modern planning and 
asset management systems and tools, such as the Highway Design and Maintenance Model, 
Version 4 (HDM-4), road asset management, project management, and other similar systems. 
 
3.  Investment Program. The consultants will do the following: 
 
(i)  Identify, screen, and prioritize about 2,500 kilometers (km) of candidate roads 
among national and provincial highways and rural access roads based on the TA 
objective and on economic, social, and other criteria. The consultants will, in 
close coordination and cooperation with the provincial and district authorities, 
adopting  a  participatory  approach,  consult  with  all  relevant  stakeholders, 
especially the poor people; and conduct public meetings and dialogues with the 
communities in the project areas to obtain feedback on the proposed candidate 
roads, and on the social and environmental mitigation measures envisaged. The 
results of the consultation and the dialogue with the communities and other 
stakeholders will be incorporated in the analysis and taken into account in the 
selection of roads.  
 
(ii)  Update existing feasibility studies,18 and prepare new ones, as appropriate, for 
the selected roads among national and provincial highways and five core rural 
access roads,19 to be included in the project following approval by the Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB),  the  Government  of  NWFP,  and  the  Federal 
Government.  
 
                                                 
18 Feasibility refers to complete appraisal of all technical; economic; financial; social including resettlement, gender, 
and poverty; and environment aspects and other related issues of the candidate roads in accordance with all 
relevant Asian Development Bank guidelines and best international practices.  
19 The feasibility and detailed engineering studies for the five core rural access roads will serve as the standard for

(iii)  As a part of the feasibility studies for selected roads, estimate the project costs 
based  on  appropriate  quantities,  unit  rates,  and  costs.  Estimate  the  foreign 
exchange (direct and indirect) and local currency costs. Show tax as a separate 
item.  Estimate  physical  contingencies.  Estimate  price  contingencies  based  on 
ADB’s international and domestic inflation rates and a constant real exchange rate. 
Estimate the costs of routine and periodic maintenance for selected roads. 
 
(iv)  As part of the feasibility studies for selected roads, carry out economic evaluation 
in accordance with ADB’s  Guidelines for Economic Analysis of Projects  and 
confirm the economic viability of selected roads based on HDM-4  economic 
analysis  and  also  quantifying  benefits  from  time  savings  and  reduction  in 
accidents. Specifically, the consultants will do the following: 
 
(a)  Carry out an economic evaluation (20-year benefit stream period) of the 
alternative improvement options for each road section and project road by 
calculating the economic internal rate of return (EIRR) based on benefits 
and  costs,  including  those  for  civil  works,  rights-of-way,  detailed 
engineering, and construction supervision. The choice between mutually 
exclusive improvement options will be based on the net present worth 
method at a discount rate of 12%.  
(b)  Identify the beneficiaries of the proposed road improvements; classify 
them according to income class; assess the poverty reduction aspects of 
the road improvements, and how many poor people would be affected in 
relation  to  the  total  population  in  the  project  influence  areas  during 
construction  and  during  the  benefit  stream  period;  and  estimate  the 
impact of the road improvements, if any, on employment of women. 
Prepare  a  distribution  analysis  of  quantified  economic  benefits  and 
estimation of poverty impact ratios for selected roads in accordance with 
ADB’s Handbook for Integrating Poverty Impact Analysis in the Economic 
Analysis of Projects. 
(c)  Undertake sensitivity tests for individual key parameters and assumptions 
and recommended improvements underlying the estimated benefits and 
costs by appropriately varying benefits, project costs, maintenance levels, 
including lower than expected levels of maintenance delivery and higher 
maintenance demand due to higher axle-loads (and their implications for 
roughness  in  the  with-  and  the  without-  Project  situations  related  to 
EIRR), and the implementation period. Calculate switching values as 
appropriate. 
(d)  Carry out quantitative risk analysis of the Project and its components in 
accordance with ADB’s  Handbook for Integrating Risk Analysis in the 
Economic Analysis of Projects. 
(v)  Update and carry out, as appropriate, detailed design and engineering for about 
400 km of the selected national and provincial highways and five core rural 
access roads including the following: 
 
(a)  Update  or  carry  out,  as  appropriate,  topographic  surveys  to  reflect 
present conditions. This will involve restoring and/or reestablishing (for 
realignment)  survey  benchmarks,  updating  topographic  maps,  and 
identifying  built-up  areas  along  the  road.  Review  and  carry  out  the

(b)  Undertake  detailed  traffic  counts,  origin-destination  surveys,  turning 
movement counts, and road roughness and axle load surveys to verify 
and/or update the original traffic and axle load studies and traffic growth 
rates.  The traffic surveys will include nonmotorized vehicles of all types. 
Analyze the new traffic and axle load data for confirming or amending the

(c)  Review the suitability of the proposed alignments, sections, and road 
intersections,  taking  into  account  safety  considerations. In particular, 
develop appropriate means of minimizing conflicts between fast-moving 
motorized traffic and slow-moving motorized and nonmotorized traffic.  
 
(d)  Review the drainage and hydrological designs proposed for the selected 
roads and prepare, as required, new designs that will provide appropriate 
drainage, vehicle standing, bus loading, pedestrian refuge, traffic control, 
and other facilities as may be required.  
 
(e)  Make  an  inventory  and  update  the  condition  of  all  bridge/culvert

prepare new designs where required for the selected roads. In particular,

C.  Reporting and Documentation Requirements 
 
4.  The consultants will prepare the following reports and documents for the Government 
and ADB, and will submit them in the numbers indicated. For ADB, and where appropriate to the 
nature of the report or document, the consultants may use electronic transmission, in which 
case the multiple copy requirement will not apply. All reports will be in English. 
 
(i)  Inception Report.  To be submitted within 3 weeks after commencement of 
services, the report will be based on the work and staffing schedules agreed 
upon  during  contract  negotiations.  It  will  (a)  summarize  initial  findings,  in 
particular for the environmental and social impact activities; and (b) highlight 
problems encountered or anticipated; and (c) recommend solutions to them. 
(W&S, 5 copies; FHA, 2 copies; ADB, 3 copies) 
 
(ii)  Progress Reports.  Brief  reports  will  be  submitted  monthly,  based  on  the 
inception report and on the implementation and staffing schedules. The reports 
will identify matters that require the attention of W&S and/or ADB. (W&S, 3 
copies; FHA, 2 copies; ADB 2 copies) 
 
(iii)  Interim Report.  A brief report to be submitted at the end of the second 
month of the service, this will set out (a) the results of the screening, and 
prioritization of candidate roads and initial economic evaluation studies; (b) initial 
findings  as  to  the  impact  of  roads  on  poverty  reduction;  and  (c)  initial 
assessments of the environmental and social impacts, and the extent to which 
they will require mitigation. (W&S, 5 copies; FHA, 2 copies, ADB, 3 copies) 
 
(iv)  Draft EIA and/or IEE Reports and Summary EIA and/or IEE Reports. Drafts 
will be submitted at the end of the fifth month of the services. Final reports will be 
submitted 1 week after receiving comments on the draft final reports from W&S 
and ADB. (W&S, 5 copies; FHA, 2 copies; ADB, 3 copies) 
 
(v)  Draft Social Impact Reports (Social Analysis, Resettlement and Poverty 
Impact Analysis), Summary Resettlement and Rehabilitation Action Plan, 
and Summary Poverty Impact Assessment. Draft will be submitted at the end 
of the fifth month of the services covering the selected roads. Final reports will be 
submitted 1 week after receiving comments on the draft final reports from W&S 
and ADB. (W&S, 5 copies; FHA, 2 copies; ADB, 3 copies) 
 
(vi)  Draft Final Report.  This will be submitted not later than the end of the fifth 
month of the services. (W&S, 5 copies; FHA, 2 copies; ADB, 3 copies) 
 
(vii)  Final Report. This will be submitted 1 week after receiving comments on the 
draft final report from W&S and ADB. An executive summary of the final report, 
condensed to about 10 pages, is also required to be submitted. The executive 
summary will be made publicly available through the ADB website or by hard 
copy. (W&S, 5 copies; FHA, 2 copies; ADB, 3 copies)
